A careless admin leaked part of RSA's private key with the encrypted flag. Can you exploit the partial key exposure to decrypt the message? Ciphertext: 607949004297736552482263794264751879667465154883791146645193761786875834683195828975349697921516634620313976085824579578060839036502736341801351458816057

The flag format is flag{...}
n=6587163267963692928214073277010163602829358693706606891896670949679239473711579484142450996727927589845463736889348955908203746420830934611007733532739189, e=3290310756035241238266601755455531352135350070928060891231312491204310141716664353945547031385007408812022710167261860846645628338708568633324277393691987, partial_p=17318588101948373292

---

## Challenge Technical Details
flag: flag{bm90n0i7}
cipher: RSA
ciphertext: 607949004297736552482263794264751879667465154883791146645193761786875834683195828975349697921516634620313976085824579578060839036502736341801351458816057
vulnerability: partial key exposure
hint: A partial exposure of a prime number's bits can significantly weaken RSA security. Look into lattice-based techniques like Coppersmith's attack.
necessary_info: The flag format is flag{...}
n=6587163267963692928214073277010163602829358693706606891896670949679239473711579484142450996727927589845463736889348955908203746420830934611007733532739189, e=3290310756035241238266601755455531352135350070928060891231312491204310141716664353945547031385007408812022710167261860846645628338708568633324277393691987, partial_p=17318588101948373292
extra_info: p=108710539429187255749667983876743637535206427979082903413076387016537858521211, q=60593602998856355050820435334817947699734118288835565194490391443063669416399, Ï†(n)=6587163267963692928214073277010163602829358693706606891896670949679239473711410180000022953117127101426252175304114015361935827952223367832548132004801580
